data.title: Josephine O'Neill's REVIEWS
data.meta_description: IT'S ABOUT: A twin murderess. YOU'LL SEE: Olivia de Havilland, Lew Ayres. ...
data.text:
cal drama frames a remark

able performance by Olivia de

Havilland.

Olivia plays the dual role of twin

sisters, identical in appearance and

opposed in character. Her interpre

tation is so thoughtful and subtle

c—r- a -i-i- that each girl becomes

O I A I l a clear-cut personality

early in the film. That

production trick of identity jewels to

distinguish the pair is unnecessary.

In fact, Olivia's is the Academy Award

work of the year — whether she wins

or not.

The Dark Mirror itself, from Uni

versal-International, is a quiet, dis

tinguished production, which obtains

an extraordinary amount of suspense

with the minimum of action. I have

only one quarrel with the script: it

gives the game away too soon.

Robert Siodmak's clever, low-keyed

direction is as unusual as his cast.

The psychiatrist who solves the mys

tery — which twin committed a mur

der — is played by Lew Ayres. Four

years older, graver and thinner, Ayres

does a fine, sensitive, and charming

job.

Thomas Mitchell, as the detective

who asks the psychiatrist's help — the

police know that one of the twins is

guiltv from the start — is in excellent

form. But then, it's a long time since

Mitchell has had so good a story.

To Sum Up: One of . the best in

its class.

Danger Signal

IT'S ABOUT: A scoundrel.

YOU'LL SEE: Zachary Scott

AS an encore for Mildred Pierce,

Warners make Zachary Scott

again a vicious philanderer — in a

darkly inferior melodrama. Its story:

r- k a i-m i-\ r- Zachary insinuates

EMPIRE himself into a fam-

ily, makes love to

two sisters in turn, takes a toss over

the cliff. Most peculiar points: the

. corny dialogue, the bad work of Faye

Emerson and Mona Freeman. Re

deeming points: Zachary, and the

game psychiatrist of Rosemary de

Camp.

To Sum Up: Tut-tut.
